blog.torresmateo.com A place to find rants and some videogame dev stuff! http://blog.torresmateo.com Un buen juez <p>Unos días atrás estuve conversando con unos amigos sobre cualquier pavada en un grupo de WhatsApp. No recuerdo exactamente cómo, pero en algún momento la conversación se torna en una conversación acerca de como está el país y se inicia un ping pong de ideas. Convencionalmente esto terminaría en un ping pong de ideas políticas con diferentes grados de tendencias a la derecha o izquierda... pero no esta vez. </p> <p>Hablamos de las ventajas y desventajas de la forma en que se maneja la justicia y se resuelven los conflictos en Paraguay, y como siempre esta discusión estaba bajo la sombra de la siempre presente corrupción y amiguismo que acompaña en la vida real todo el proceso.</p> <p>En algún punto de la conversación propuse que se deje en manos de una computadora la resolución de casos simples y cuyos resultados sean obvios...</p> <p>¿Una locura... verdad? </p> <p>Este post es acerca de porqué yo creo que esto no es tan loco como parece y algunas ideas iniciales de cómo podría implementarse un &quot;juez electrónico&quot;. Me enfoco en los principales obstáculos de la implementación. </p> <h1>La lógica de la justicia (la ley)</h1> <p>Las leyes se basan en la lógica... En particular, en la lógica jurídica. La lógica jurídica a su vez depende del lenguaje en que están escritos los artículos y esta por supuesto sujeta a interpretación debido a las ambigüedades del lenguaje. Esto en mi opinión es razonable si asumimos que el juez es incorruptible e imparcial. En la vida real (y especialmente en Paraguay) esto no ocurre. Por lo tanto, se requiere de una lógica formal y no contradictoria que pueda modelar la ley actual.</p> <p>Ciertamente modelar la lógica jurídica con artículos muy generales y sus miles de posibles interpretaciones es una tarea compleja. Pero el juez digital no precisa de esto, ya que existe una parte no contradictoria en la ley que es posible modelar como una lógica formal. Aunque el juez digital no pueda resolver los casos más complejos, podría alivianar la carga a seres humanos o al menos dar sugerencias fundamentadas en la ley en conflictos menores. </p> <p>En mi opinión esto es más que suficiente para mejorar sustancialmente la justicia en Paraguay.</p> <h1>Machine Learning y Big Data</h1> <p>La ciencia de la computación en estos días es tal que permite utilizar la experiencia en otros campos para tomar mejores decisiones. En sus inicios esto estaba limitado por la escasez de datos disponibles para inferir cualquier tipo de patrón. </p> <p>Hoy en día sin embargo, la cantidad de información disponible en cualquier campo de investigación es sin duda abrumadora para cualquier ser humano. Pero se ha demostrado (con <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaGo">AlphaGo</a> por ejemplo) que se vuelve posible este tipo de decisiones de forma exitosa.</p> <h1>El juez perfecto</h1> <p>Quizás el punto principal y más importante del juez digital es que no propongo un juez perfecto. Sólo propongo un juez que sea más justo y eficiente que el sistema actual. Estoy muy de acuerdo en que la tarea de hacer un juez automático que compita con un ser humano incorruptible es casi imposible. Pero teniendo en cuenta que hoy en día la justicia en Paraguay es en muchos casos un absurdo extremo, no veo porqué no darle una oportunidad a esta idea. Al final de cuentas, a este juez no se le va a poder comprar.</p> Sat, 23 Apr 2016 07:17:00 +0100 http://blog.torresmateo.com//es/opinion/2016/04/23/un-buen-juez.html http://blog.torresmateo.com//es/opinion/2016/04/23/un-buen-juez.html First Month in the UK <p>It&#39;s been a while since I updated this thingy... Claramente esto afecta al ritmo de la conversación y a veces incluso genera que se pierda el <em>rapport</em> que había hasta ese microsegundo anterior a que me quede colgado. Estoy seguro de que no solo me pasa a mi... pero ultimamente la verdaaad es que cada vez me lo hacen notar con más frecuencia.</p> <p>Para no dar muchas vueltas, la realidad es que en esos momentos NO me quedo colgado, pero estoy considerando que responder, y quizás estoy considerando <em>varias</em> cosas que responder. Algo que no me explico es ¿como es que esto se da en conversaciones triviales de la vida? Sinceramente, NI IDEA.... PERO!! Tengo una teoría de porque me pasa a mi (y quizás también sea así para vos!).</p> <p>Cada vez es más necesario para mí hacerme muchas preguntas. Esto se debe principalmente a que me estoy dedicando un poco más a la investigación y a diseñar soluciones a diverso tipo de problemas (informáticos por lo general). Este ejercicio mental hace que la mayor parte de mi actividad productiva sea &quot;dentro&quot; de mi cabeza. Me gusta pensar que estoy progresando porque cada vez puedo considerar más factores al encarar un problema y las soluciones resultantes se vuelven mas &quot;elegantes&quot; que las soluciones que proponía hace un año.</p> <p>Me parece que un efecto de estar mucho tiempo pensando de esta manera, hace que ante cualquier trivialidad tienda a analizar cada vez más factores dentro del contexto de la conversación. El efecto de esto? Estoy ahi como una computadora cuando se cuelga... <em>sin un output</em> que de evidencia de que sigo en el &quot;mundo real&quot;. </p> <h1>¿Es esto algo negativo?</h1> <p>Si. Mantener una conversación fluida es un aspecto muy importante de la vida del ser humano. Y pensar mucho en algo innecesario es una pérdida de energía y tiempo que finalmente no lleva a nada. Ciertamente nada es absoluto y hay ocasiones en las que uno tiene que considerar muchas cosas antes de responder (como por ejemplo una entrevista de trabajo, un debate, etc.)</p> <h1>¿Que puedo hacer al respecto?</h1> <p>Personalmente, trato conscientemente de no irme mucho por las ramas de pensamiento cuando estoy conversando. Cuando creo que es algo demasiado importante como para evitar pensar bastante antes de responder, trato de dar algún tipo de <em>feedback</em> al interlocutor (algo como &quot;Dejame pensar un ratito&quot; o ponerme un una típica pose de pensador, como agarrarme la barba).</p> <h1>¿Eso funciona?</h1> <p>Más o menos. Este ejercicio mental hace que disminuya en cierto grado el corte en la fluidez de las conversaciones que tengo cotidianamente. Si te pasa algo similar, te cuento que es un poco frustrante no tener la libertad de pensar mucho antes de responder y &quot;arriesgarte&quot; a dar una respuesta de la que después te puedas arrepentir. Pero ayuda un poco pensar que hablar en &quot;tiempo real&quot; es una habilidad muy buena, y optimizar la cantidad de pensamiento que se da a un tema antes de responder es una habilidad muy deseable para la vida.</p> <blockquote> <p>Advertencia: Este es un post basado en opiniones y una investigación informal y poco profunda de un tema que no conozco muy bien.</p> </blockquote> Tue, 21 Jul 2015 07:17:00 +0100 http://blog.torresmateo.com//es/opinion/2015/07/21/quedarse-colgado.html http://blog.torresmateo.com//es/opinion/2015/07/21/quedarse-colgado.html Ingeniería, la vida... y World of Warcraft <p>Buenas a todos!!</p> <p>Después de 5 meses y alguito decidí invertir un poco de tiempo en renovar el blog y justificar lo que gasté en el dominio!</p> <p>Pasaron muchas cosas desde enero y van a ver en las siguientes secciones todo lo que estuve haciendo desde enero hasta acá, incluyendo algunas cosas de antes de enero que no incluí en otros posts porque no quería mezclar tanto temas generales con desarrollo de videojuegos y cosas de informática en general.</p> <blockquote> <p>Antes de seguir con el post, enumero los cambios al blog que vinieron con este post!</p> <ul> <li>Mejora general del estilo (desde mi punto de vista de programador!).</li> <li>Sección en Español (para este tipo de posts que son más para mi familia/amigos que manuales de informática y cosas así). For instance, if you have to make a game like <a href="/evolution/gaming/dev/2014/01/10/ui-design.html">Bacteria</a>, the obvious choice is <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha%E2%80%93beta_pruning">Alpha-Beta pruning</a>.</p> <h2>The Story</h2> <p>The assignment Fer and I had was <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backgammon">Backgammon</a>. It&#39;s a board game with checkers and dices. The main goal is to move your checkers from your &quot;house&quot; to the opponent&#39;s. In your turn you throw a pair of dices, and move the checkers forward. If you&#39;ve got the same result in both dices, you earn a double turn, moving four times.</p> <p>It&#39;s actually a boring game, compared to chess, but Fer and I learned how to play, and even watched YouTube videos of the world championship.</p> <p>When this assignment was given, one of the requirements was to use alpha-beta pruning for the AI. It didn&#39;t feel right to me, because adding dices to the mix leaves you with a lot of randomness. Of course you can modify alpha-beta to deal with the randomness, but as I&#39;ve said above, there are A LOT of options, and it&#39;s part of the art of problem solving to pick the right tool for the job.</p> <p>In class, I asked our teacher about this, and he didn&#39;t answer my question. I stayed after class to him again, and we had an argument about the right algorithm to use for the game.</p> <h2>The implementation</h2> <p>Graphically, it&#39;s the same as <a href="/evolution/gaming/dev/2014/01/10/ui-design.html">Bacteria</a>. Even the mouse handler is 90% taken from our previous implementation, we used color masks and sprites. <a href="http://alleg.sourceforge.net/">Allegro</a> was also the library we used again.</p> <p>The difference was AI. We had to learn some useful strategies for backgammon. The game has two logical stages. In the first stage, the opponent can block your checkers, and this means a lot of computation towards avoiding that, and focusing on desirable board configurations. In the second stage it&#39;s simply a &quot;race&quot;, the first player to reach the opponent&#39;s &quot;home&quot; wins the game. We implemented a weight based heuristic for both stages.</p> <p>The first heuristic was focused in achieving good board configurations, we had points for:</p> <ul> <li>Distance to the opponent&#39;s home (low priority)</li> <li>Avoid blocked checkers (medium priority)</li> <li>Block opponent&#39;s checkers (medium priority)</li> <li>Occupy six adjacent columns (high priority)</li> </ul> <p>There were other aspects, but these four are the most important. The last one was added after watching a lot of (boring) backgammon games online. Professional players seemed to aim for a particular board configuration. When you have two or more checkers in the same column, the opponent can&#39;t block your checkers in that column, so having six consecutive columns occupied means you own a &quot;wall&quot; of columns that the other player can&#39;t pass.</p> <p>The second stage has the following priorities:</p> <ul> <li>Distance to the opponent&#39;s home (high priority)</li> <li>Everything else (no priority)</li> </ul> <p>Basically, it&#39;s focused on reaching the opponent&#39;s home.</p> <h2>The tournament</h2> <p>The main goal of this implementation was to make every team challenge other&#39;s programs. It was fun, at first we won because most of our classmates&#39; programs weren&#39;t finished. We ended with 3 complete games (best of 3), the first two we won 2-0, and the last one (the final game of the tournament) was our program against Rafael Arias Michel and Daniel Ruffinelli&#39;s implementation, I&#39;ll refer to them as <em>Rafa</em> and <em>Ruffo</em> from now on unless they ask me not to, in which case I&#39;ll probably keep calling them <em>Rafa</em> and <em>Ruffo</em>.</p> <p>They had a nice implementation in GTK, and if I remember correctly they had implemented Alpha-Beta Pruning. Our program won the first match, the second one we lost! By that moment we had an audience (about 6 classmates who were interested enough to stay and watch a bunch of nerds cheering for their own implementation of a complete boring board game). The last game was interesting, both programs made mistakes, specially at the end. We could not tell who had the advantage until the very end.</p> <p>Luckily we won :)</p> <h2>Video and Code</h2> <p>Last, but not least, here&#39;s the video of me playing (and winning!) against my own implementation. The interface this time isn&#39;t as elaborated as in Bacteria, but the main reasons were:</p> <ul> <li>The objective was not to make a playable PC vs Player game, we did it for completeness.</li> <li>Backgammon is boring.</li> <li>We focused on the PC vs PC tournament instead of Interface and/or Design, I think it looks OK though.</li> <li>Backgammon is boring.</li> <li>Did I mention how boring Backgammon is?</li> </ul> <p><strong>WARNING:</strong> It&#39;s about 4 minutes of myself playing a boring game :)</p> <iframe width="800" height="600" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/dKyYiN4sj7s?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> <p>and as always... the <a href="https://github.com/torresmateo/Backgammon">code</a>.</p> Wed, 19 Mar 2014 06:10:00 +0000 http://blog.torresmateo.com//evolution/gaming/dev/2014/03/19/backgammon.html http://blog.torresmateo.com//evolution/gaming/dev/2014/03/19/backgammon.html Bacteria, Part 2: Gameplay, Drag & Drop and other Stuff <p>This is the second part of the Bacteria development, I&#39;ll focus in gameplay, and the technique we used for implementing drag and drop with Allegro.</p> <h2>Gameplay</h2> <p>First, I&#39;ll give a little introduction of what gameplay is:</p> <blockquote> <p>Gameplay is the specific way in which players interact with a game, and in particular with video games. Gameplay is the pattern defined through the game rules, connection between player and the game, challenges and overcoming them, plot and player&#39;s connection with it. Video game gameplay is distinct from graphics, and audio elements. <div style="text-align:right;">&#8213;Random Dude in Wikipedia</div></p> </blockquote> <p>That should be clear enough.</p> <p>For our game, we wanted the player to focus in the strategic part of the game, and not to deal with an uncomfortable way of interacting with objects on the screen. In our previous games the player had to learn a bunch of &quot;complicated&quot; controls to do things, and it wasn&#39;t fun to play that way.</p> <h2>Drag &amp; Drop</h2> <p>Since Bacteria is a board game, the intuitive way to interact with it is obviously the mouse. Here&#39;s a list of the things you can do with any mouse:</p> <ul> <li>Move pointer.</li> <li>Click.</li> <li>Right-Click.</li> </ul> <p>Pretty limited. I didn&#39;t include <em>scroll</em> in that list because (sadly) not all mice have a scroll wheel. So, handling the mouse is not as simple as it can appear at first sight... aaaand right-clicking sucks in a board game... so... here&#39;s our new list:</p> <ul> <li>Move pointer.</li> <li>Click.</li> </ul> <p>But wait!! If you think about it, there are special things about the click event, and it&#39;s all about timing. In every mouse based interface you have more options:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Double-click:</strong> Click two times, fast. It&#39;s like clicking, but if almost every time a single-click is <code>select</code>, double click is <code>open</code> or, in a more general way: <code>interact</code> with the double-clicked element.</li> <li><strong>Drag-and-Drop:</strong> It&#39;s done by pressing on the element, moving the mouse while still pressing the mouse button, and then releasing the button in another area in the screen.</li> </ul> <p>These options are called <em>gestures</em>. We were interested in <em>Drag-and-Drop</em>, because it&#39;s the simplest way to &quot;move&quot; one object over the scene. The basic idea is click and hold one of the little bacteria, and somehow give the player the feeling that s/he is &quot;holding&quot; the object as long as the mouse button is pressed. We implemented this feature by doing the following:</p> <ul> <li><strong>On mouse press:</strong> Quickly swap the bacteria with a &quot;phantom&quot; version, useful to know the original position in the board. Also, replace the mouse pointer, our choice was the same pointer with a bacteria attached to it, so wherever the player moved the mouse, the bacteria seemed to be glued to the pointer.</li> <li><strong>On mouse release:</strong> Swap the pointer image to the original (the one without the bacteria attached). If the player released in a valid cell, the original cell now looks like an empty cell, and the new cell now hold a bacteria. If the player released in any other place, the phantom version returns to be the normal bacteria.</li> </ul> <p>It worked like a charm!!</p> <p>Here&#39;s an image showing the empty cell, the &quot;phantom&quot; bacteria , the &quot;infected&quot; cell, and both pointers. </p> <p><img src="http://blog.torresmateo.com/images/bacteria-part-2/blue_bacteria.png" alt="" title="Blue Bacteria"></p> <h2>Artificial Intelligence</h2> <p>Some words about the intelligence.</p> <p>First of all, we knew absolutely NOTHING about game theory at the time, and I think we did pretty well taking that into account. </p> <p>Our implementation was a tree-like decision structure. We started by assuming the enemy played the best he could, and the AI moves acted accordingly. It&#39;s pretty clever after reading the code almost 4 years later =). It&#39;s not very hard to beat the computer with this AI, but not ultra-easy though, it takes to think at least two moves ahead to win. </p> <h1>Finally</h1> <p>Well... I wrote a LOT about Bacteria, and after reading it myself I decided it was long and boring, so I erased all of it and instead made a video of myself showing what I think are the best parts of this game:</p> <ul> <li>Menus... they look AWESOME!!.</li> <li>Board Editor.</li> <li>Game.</li> <li>Instruction Pages.</li> </ul> <p>It&#39;s not a long video, and I lose (in my defense, the purpose of this wasn&#39;t for me to win, but to show the features).</p> <iframe width="800" height="600" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/H9hrEwQNlbw?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> <h1>To be continued...</h1> <p>The next post is not about Bacteria. It&#39;s about Backgammon, but only the AI part, since all the rest is pretty similar to Bacteria, the interesting part is the intelligence. I plan to make another video for that post, since it&#39;s much easier for me to show the features that way, and maybe it&#39;s a better experience to you to actually see the interactivity and other things that can&#39;t be seen properly in still images.</p> Tue, 04 Feb 2014 06:00:00 +0000 http://blog.torresmateo.com//evolution/gaming/dev/2014/02/04/bacteria-part-2.html http://blog.torresmateo.com//evolution/gaming/dev/2014/02/04/bacteria-part-2.html Bacteria, Part 1: UI Design <p>One of the projects I feel proud about is called Bacteria (a modified version of <a href="http://hexxagon.com/">Hexxagon</a>). We had absolutely no clue of what to do, nor where to start. There were just too many thing to take into account.</p> <p>Hexxagon is a board game. To make it fun, it <em>needs</em> a good <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphical_user_interface">GUI</a>, and a LOT of interactive features. </p> <p>To make it easy, here is one possible board, each hexagon is a cell:</p> <p><img src="http://blog.torresmateo.com/images/bacteria/hexboard.png" alt="" title="possible board"></p> <ul> <li><p>Rules:</p> <ul> <li>Same as Hexxagon, two types of moves, you can <em>multiply</em> to a cell next to yours, or you can <em>jump</em> over one cell in an hexagonal board.</li> <li>The winner is the player who owns more cells when the board has no free cells.</li> </ul></li> <li><p>For our particular implementation, we had to add this:</p> <ul> <li>A hint about where you can jump, or multiply.</li> <li>A board editor.</li> <li>Multiplayer Feature based on a given XML Protocol (Maybe I&#39;ll describe the protocol in the next post).</li> <li>Sound.</li> </ul></li> </ul> <p>So, at first sight, it doesn&#39;t seem like a LOT, but we wanted to make a great game out of this.</p> <h2>Rules and Logic</h2> <p>Programming the game logic wasn&#39;t really hard. But we were enjoying the development proccess like a child who gets a Nintendo 64 on Christmas! After reading about SDL, GTK and other options we ended up using <a href="http://alleg.sourceforge.net/">Allegro</a>, a Game Programming Library.</p> <p>The first challenge was &quot;how the hell are we going to make this pretty&quot;. I started making drafts in paper and we would discuss with Fer the good and the bad of every menu and how it should work. It was clear we needed a cell that worked like a brick, so we can build many different boards (with holes, or two separate &quot;islands&quot;).</p> <p>This image shows a possible board, the first image is our board editor, and the second is the game view with the statistics. I still look at this and can&#39;t help a little smile of satisfaction and pride :&#39;D</p> <p><img src="http://blog.torresmateo.com/images/bacteria/board_editor.png" alt="" title="Our Board Editor"> <img src="http://blog.torresmateo.com/images/bacteria/game_view.png" alt="" title="Game View"></p> <p>Note the cell borders in the game view. If you&#39;re reading this, you&#39;ve seen how easily I get distracted by other stuff that seems to be interesting. I think ( and hope) that thinking regularly about my actual dream will somehow help me achieve it. It&#39;s silly, but I won&#39;t lose anything more than a few hours a week writing this and maybe some of my keyboard’s painting.</li> </ol> <p>That being said...
